bibl.title: Letter from Juan Guiteras to Howard A. Kelly, November 12, 1905

div1.p: Guiteras responds to negative publicity about sanitary work in Panama. He states that neglect of mosquito work in the American South is the result of “moneyed interests”. He offers favorable recollections of Walter Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Juan Guiteras to Howard A. Kelly, November 12, 1905
div1.opener:
DR. JUAN GUITERAS
HOSPITAL “LAS ANIMAS”
HABANA
---
November 12th. 1905
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
Dear Dr. Kelly:
div1.p:
your kind and pleasant letter reaches me when I am in
trouble; and I shall have no time to write you as I would have liked
to do. Our good work of more than four years has suddenly broken down.
An epidemic of dengue we have had through the Summer evidently prevent-
ed us from recognising some mild case of yellow fever, and we have now
a secondary crop of cases. I believe we shall stop it before it becomes
epidemic. You try and help us to get fair play. Moneyed interests in
your country are at work constantly against us. Senator Cullom a few
days ago presented to the President information to the effect that we
were neglecting sanitation, and that we were threatened with an epid-
emic. Of so many prophets of evil as we have heard of at the rate of
three or four a year, at last Mr. Cullom did hit it. But these men are
doing your Southern section serious injury. They are specially interest
ed in sewarage and paving jobs, and they talk of our neglect in these
matters as the threatening cause of our coming outbreak. With this the
teaching of the mosquito doctrine in the South is being neglected. He
Hence the reason why your Sothern country has had the fever twice to
our once. The Herald and the informers of Senator Cullom will not let
the South know that if we have yellow fever today it is simply because
a case has slipped in upon us unawares; and if we stop the disease to-
morrow it will be because we have killed all the mosquitos that have
become infected.

It is sad to contemplate that the country of Reed has been among
the last to profit from his work. He was a grat and a lovable man.
I remember well the days when he was keeping his secret from us. It
was not the air of mistery of the conceited man who is glorying in his
superiority, nor that of the sordid man who is thinking of the profit
DR. JUAN GUITERAS
HOSPITAL “LAS ANIMAS”
HABANA
---
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
he is to obtain from his secret. No, the merry twinkle in his blue eye
was expressive of the anticipated enjoyment of the pleasure that he
had in store for us all. To me one of the sweetest traits in his charac
ter was the respect, the esteem, the love he felt for the great master,
Finlay. There was something of the filial attitude in his brief intercourse
with Finlay. He had taken up, and brought to a glourious completeness
the work of the great thinker.
Thank you for the kind remembrance of the days of Blockley.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours John Guiteras American medicine will have shortly
a paper of mine on the work done
in Habana. I am returning proof.
